Dry Locations Without Jacket - Insulation mils
Dry Locations With Jacket - Insulation mm
Dry Locations With Jacket - Insulation mils
Dry Locations With Jacket - Jacket mm
Dry Locations With Jacket - Jacket mils
Wet or Dry Single Conductor - Insulation mm
Wet or Dry Single Conductor - Insulation mils
Wet or Dry Single Conductor - Jacket mm
Wet or Dry Single Conductor - Jacket mils
Table 315.10(B).note: Under a common overall covering such as a jacket, sheath, or armor.

Table 315.10(C).caption: Thickness of Insulation for Shielded Solid Dielectric Insulated Conductors Rated 2001 Volts to 35,000 Volts
Table 315.10(C).description: Specifies required insulation thickness for shielded medium voltage conductors rated 2001-35,000 volts based on conductor size, voltage rating, and insulation level percentage. Three insulation levels provided: 100% level for grounded systems with rapid fault clearing (under 1 minute), 133% level for systems where neutral voltage varies from line-to-ground voltage, and 173% level for ungrounded systems or longer fault clearing times. Covers six voltage ranges: 2001-5000V, 5001-8000V, 8001-15,000V, 15,001-25,000V, 25,001-28,000V, and 28,001-35,000V. Minimum conductor sizes increase with voltage: 2 AWG minimum for lower voltages up to 1 AWG for 15kV+ systems. Insulation thickness ranges from 2.29mm (90 mils) at lowest voltage/100% level to 14.73mm (580 mils) at 35kV/173% level. Required by NEC 315.10(C) for shielded MV cable construction standards to ensure safe operation based on system grounding and fault protection capabilities.

Table 315.12(A).caption: Minimum Size of Conductors
Table 315.12(A).description: Specifies minimum conductor size requirements for medium voltage (MV) cables based on voltage rating from 2001 volts to 35,000 volts. Applies to copper, aluminum, and copper-clad aluminum conductors. Minimum sizes increase with voltage level: 8 AWG minimum for 2001-5000V systems, 6 AWG for 5001-8000V, 2 AWG for 8001-15,000V, 1 AWG for 15,001-28,000V, and 1/0 AWG for 28,001-35,000V systems. These minimums ensure adequate mechanical strength and current-carrying capacity for MV applications in industrial, commercial, and utility distribution systems. Note that some manufacturers may not produce MV cables in the smallest allowable sizes, so availability should be verified during design phase. Required by NEC 315.12(A) for safe medium voltage conductor installation regardless of calculated ampacity requirements.
headers: Minimum Conductor Size (AWG) - Copper, Aluminum, or Copper-Clad Aluminum

Table 315.60(C)(1).caption: Ampacities of Insulated Single Copper Conductor Cables Triplexed in Air
Table 315.60(C)(1).description: Provides ampacity ratings for single copper medium voltage conductors arranged in triplexed configuration (three-phase set bundled together) in free air. Covers conductor sizes 8 AWG through 1000 kcmil with ratings for both MV-90 (90°C) and MV-105 (105°C) insulation types. Separate columns for 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V voltage ranges. Triplexed configuration provides higher ampacities than individual isolated conductors due to bundling heat effects. Ampacities range from 65A for 8 AWG at lower voltage to 980A for 1000 kcmil at higher temperature rating. Based on 40°C ambient temperature; requires correction factors from Table 315.60(D)(4) for other ambient temperatures. Used for sizing medium voltage conductors in aerial installations, cable trays, or other free-air applications. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(1) for proper MV copper conductor ampacity determination in triplexed air installations.
Table 315.60(C)(1).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for the basis of ampacities, 315.10(A) for conductor maximum operating temperature and application, and 315.60(D)(4) for the ampacity correction factors where the ambient air temperature is other than 40°C (104°F).

Table 315.60(C)(10).caption: Ampacities of an Insulated Three-Conductor Aluminum Cable in Isolated Conduit in Air
Table 315.60(C)(10).description: Provides ampacity ratings for three-conductor aluminum medium voltage cable (all three phases in single cable assembly) installed within an isolated conduit exposed to air. Covers conductor sizes 8 AWG through 1000 kcmil with ratings for both MV-90 (90°C) and MV-105 (105°C) insulation types. Separate columns for 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V voltage ranges. Installation method means conduit containing three-conductor cable is in free air (not buried or embedded) allowing external cooling through conduit walls. Three-conductor cable has mutual heating within cable jacket, plus conduit confinement further reduces ampacity. Aluminum ampacities approximately 75-80% of equivalent copper cable ratings. Ampacities range from 41A for 8 AWG to 615A for 1000 kcmil. Based on 40°C ambient temperature; requires correction factors from Table 315.60(D)(4) for other conditions. Used when pulling single aluminum three-phase cable through above-ground conduit where cost savings justify aluminum use. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(10) for proper MV three-conductor aluminum cable ampacity determination in isolated conduit in air.
Table 315.60(C)(10).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for the basis of ampacities, 315.10(A) for conductor maximum operating temperature and application, and 315.60(D)(4) for the ampacity correction factors where the ambient air temperature is other than 40°C (104°F).

Table 315.60(C)(11).caption: Ampacities of Three Single-Insulated Copper Conductors in Underground Electrical Ducts (Three Conductors per Electrical Duct)
Table 315.60(C)(11).description: Provides ampacity ratings for three single copper medium voltage conductors installed together in underground electrical ducts (conduit buried in earth). Covers conductor sizes 8 AWG through 1000 kcmil with ratings for both MV-90 (90°C) and MV-105 (105°C) insulation types. Separate columns for 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V voltage ranges. Table organized by number of circuits in duct bank: One Circuit (highest ampacity), Three Circuits (moderate ampacity reduction), and Six Circuits (lowest ampacity due to mutual heating from adjacent ducts). Installation method means three conductors bundled in single underground conduit. Based on earth temperature 20°C (68°F), RHO 90 thermal resistivity. Ampacities range from 48A (8 AWG, 6 circuits) to 720A (1000 kcmil, 1 circuit). Most common underground MV installation method for industrial facilities, utility substations, and commercial distribution. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(11) for proper copper MV conductor ampacity determination in underground duct banks.
Table 315.60(C)(11).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for basis of ampacities and Table 315.10(A) for the temperature rating of the conductor.

Table 315.60(C)(12).caption: Ampacities of Three Single-Insulated Aluminum Conductors in Underground Electrical Ducts (Three Conductors per Electrical Duct)
Table 315.60(C)(12).description: Provides ampacity ratings for three single aluminum medium voltage conductors installed together in underground electrical ducts. Covers conductor sizes 8 AWG through 1000 kcmil with ratings for both MV-90 (90°C) and MV-105 (105°C) insulation types. Separate columns for 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V voltage ranges. Table organized by number of circuits in duct bank: One Circuit, Three Circuits, and Six Circuits. Aluminum ampacities approximately 75-80% of equivalent copper ratings. Based on earth temperature 20°C, RHO 90 thermal resistivity. Ampacities range from 38A (8 AWG, 6 circuits) to 590A (1000 kcmil, 1 circuit). Used for underground MV distribution where cost savings justify aluminum. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(12) for proper aluminum MV conductor ampacity determination in underground duct banks.
Table 315.60(C)(12).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for basis of ampacities and Table 315.10(A) for the temperature rating of the conductor.

Table 315.60(C)(13).caption: Ampacities of Three Insulated Copper Conductors Cabled Within an Overall Covering (Three-Conductor Cable) in Underground Electrical Ducts (One Cable per Electrical Duct)
Table 315.60(C)(13).description: Provides ampacity ratings for three-conductor copper medium voltage cables in underground ducts. Single three-phase cable per duct with all conductors under common jacket. Covers 8 AWG-1000 kcmil, MV-90/MV-105, 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V. Three sections: One Circuit (59-645A), Three Circuits (53-520A), Six Circuits (46-420A). Lower ampacities than individual conductors due to mutual heating within cable jacket plus duct confinement. Earth temperature 20°C, RHO 90. Common for underground installations where single cable pull preferred. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(13).
Table 315.60(C)(13).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for basis of ampacities and Table 315.10(A) for the temperature rating of the conductor.

Table 315.60(C)(14).caption: Ampacities of Three Insulated Aluminum Conductors Cabled Within an Overall Covering (Three-Conductor Cable) in Underground Electrical Ducts (One Cable per Electrical Duct)
Table 315.60(C)(14).description: Aluminum version of Table 315.60(C)(13). Three-conductor aluminum MV cable in underground ducts. Covers 8 AWG-1000 kcmil, MV-90/MV-105, 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V. Three sections by circuit count: One Circuit (46-535A), Three Circuits (41-430A), Six Circuits (36-345A). Aluminum ampacities ~75-80% of copper equivalent. Common for cost-effective underground MV distribution. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(14).
Table 315.60(C)(14).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for basis of ampacities and Table 315.10(A) for the temperature rating of the conductor.

Table 315.60(C)(15).caption: Ampacities of Single Insulated Copper Conductors Directly Buried in Earth
Table 315.60(C)(15).description: Highest MV copper ampacity table for direct burial installation. Single copper conductors buried directly in earth (no conduit) providing maximum heat dissipation. Covers 8 AWG-1000 kcmil, MV-90/MV-105, 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V. Two sections: One Circuit 3-conductors (110-1055A) and Two Circuits 6-conductors (95-960A). Based on earth 20°C, RHO 90, burial depth per 300.5(A). Ampacities 30-50% higher than duct bank due to direct earth contact cooling. Common for utility transmission, large industrial feeders, and remote installations where trenching possible. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(15) for copper MV direct burial.

sections.section: One Circuit, Three Conductors [See Figure 315.60(D)(3), Detail 9.]
Two Circuits, Six Conductors [See Figure 315.60(D)(3), Detail 10.]

Table 315.60(C)(15).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for basis of ampacities and Table 315.10(A) for the temperature rating of the conductor.

Table 315.60(C)(16).caption: Ampacities of Single Insulated Aluminum Conductors Directly Buried in Earth
Table 315.60(C)(16).description: Aluminum version of Table 315.60(C)(15). Single aluminum conductors buried directly in earth (no conduit) for maximum heat dissipation. Covers 8 AWG-1000 kcmil, MV-90/MV-105, 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V. Two sections: One Circuit 3-conductors (85-840A) and Two Circuits 6-conductors (80-765A). Aluminum ampacities ~75-80% of copper equivalent. Ampacities 30-50% higher than duct bank due to direct earth contact cooling. Common for cost-effective underground MV distribution where trenching feasible. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(16) for aluminum MV direct burial.

sections.section: One Circuit, Three Conductors [See Figure 315.60(D)(3), Detail 9.]
Two Circuits, Six Conductors [See Figure 315.60(D)(3), Detail 10.]

Table 315.60(C)(16).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for basis of ampacities and Table 315.10(A) for the temperature rating of the conductor.

Table 315.60(C)(17).caption: Ampacities of Three Insulated Copper Conductors Cabled Within an Overall Covering (Three-Conductor Cable), Directly Buried in Earth
Table 315.60(C)(17).description: Copper three-conductor MV cable directly buried in earth (no conduit). All three phases under common jacket buried directly for optimal cooling. Covers 8 AWG-1000 kcmil, MV-90/MV-105, 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V. Two sections: One Circuit (85-785A) and Two Circuits (80-715A). Higher ampacities than duct bank installation due to direct earth contact. Lower than individual conductors due to mutual heating within cable jacket. Common where single cable pull preferred in direct burial applications. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(17) for copper 3-conductor cable direct burial.
Table 315.60(C)(17).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for basis of ampacities and Table 315.10(A) for the temperature rating of the conductor.

Table 315.60(C)(18).caption: Ampacities of Three Insulated Aluminum Conductors Cabled Within an Overall Covering (Three-Conductor Cable), Directly Buried in Earth
Table 315.60(C)(18).description: Aluminum three-conductor MV cable directly buried in earth. Aluminum version of Table 315.60(C)(17). Covers 8 AWG-1000 kcmil, MV-90/MV-105, 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V. Two sections: One Circuit (65-650A) and Two Circuits (60-590A). Aluminum ampacities ~75-80% of copper equivalent. Higher than duct bank due to direct earth contact, lower than individual conductors due to mutual heating in cable jacket. Cost-effective direct burial option for MV distribution. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(18) for aluminum 3-conductor cable direct burial.
Table 315.60(C)(18).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for basis of ampacities and Table 315.10(A) for the temperature rating of the conductor.

Table 315.60(C)(19).caption: Ampacities of Three Triplexed Single Insulated Copper Conductors Directly Buried in Earth
Table 315.60(C)(19).description: Copper triplexed (three single conductors bundled together) directly buried in earth without conduit. Three-phase set bundled and buried for optimal heat dissipation. Covers 8 AWG-1000 kcmil, MV-90/MV-105, 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V. Two sections: One Circuit 3-conductors (90-885A) and Two Circuits 6-conductors (85-795A). Higher ampacities than three-conductor cable due to less restrictive bundling. Direct earth contact provides better cooling than duct bank. Common for underground MV feeders where individual conductor flexibility needed. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(19) for copper triplexed direct burial.

sections.section: One Circuit, Three Conductors [See Figure 315.60(D)(3), Detail 7.]
Two Circuits, Six Conductors [See Figure 315.60(D)(3), Detail 8.]

Table 315.60(C)(19).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for basis of ampacities and Table 315.10(A) for the temperature rating of the conductor.

Table 315.60(C)(2).caption: Ampacities of Insulated Single Aluminum Conductor Cables Triplexed in Air
Table 315.60(C)(2).description: Provides ampacity ratings for single aluminum medium voltage conductors arranged in triplexed configuration (three-phase set bundled together) in free air. Covers conductor sizes 8 AWG through 1000 kcmil with ratings for both MV-90 (90°C) and MV-105 (105°C) insulation types. Separate columns for 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V voltage ranges. Aluminum ampacities are approximately 75-80% of equivalent copper ratings due to higher resistance. Triplexed configuration means three single conductors bundled together for three-phase power distribution. Ampacities range from 50A for 8 AWG to 800A for 1000 kcmil. Based on 40°C ambient temperature; requires correction factors from Table 315.60(D)(4) for other conditions. Used for sizing aluminum MV conductors in aerial installations, cable trays, or other free-air applications where cost savings justify aluminum use. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(2) for proper MV aluminum conductor ampacity determination in triplexed air installations.
Table 315.60(C)(2).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for basis of ampacities, 315.10(A) for conductor maximum operating temperature and application, and 315.60(D)(4) for the ampacity correction factors where the ambient air temperature is other than 40°C (104°F).

Table 315.60(C)(20).caption: Ampacities of Three Triplexed Single Insulated Aluminum Conductors Directly Buried in Earth
Table 315.60(C)(20).description: Aluminum triplexed (three single conductors bundled) directly buried in earth. Aluminum version of Table 315.60(C)(19). Covers 8 AWG-1000 kcmil, MV-90/MV-105, 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V. Two sections: One Circuit 3-conductors (70-725A) and Two Circuits 6-conductors (65-645A). Aluminum ampacities ~75-80% of copper equivalent. Triplexed configuration provides better cooling than cable jacket. Direct earth contact superior to duct bank. Cost-effective alternative to copper for direct burial MV installations. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(20) for aluminum triplexed direct burial.

sections.section: One Circuit, Three Conductors [See Figure 315.60(D)(3), Detail 7.]
Two Circuits, Six Conductors [See Figure 315.60(D)(3), Detail 8.]

Table 315.60(C)(20).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for basis of ampacities and Table 315.10(A) for the temperature rating of the conductor.

Table 315.60(C)(3).caption: Ampacities of Insulated Single Copper Conductor Isolated in Air
Table 315.60(C)(3).description: Provides highest ampacity ratings for single copper medium voltage conductors installed isolated in free air with maximum heat dissipation. Covers conductor sizes 8 AWG through 2000 kcmil with ratings for both MV-90 (90°C) and MV-105 (105°C) insulation types. Three voltage range columns: 2001-5000V, 5001-15000V, and 15001-35000V. Isolated installation means conductors spaced apart (not touching or bundled) allowing maximum cooling from all sides, resulting in highest possible ampacities compared to other installation methods. Ampacities range from 83A for 8 AWG to 1790A for 2000 kcmil at highest temperature rating. Based on 40°C ambient temperature; requires correction factors from Table 315.60(D)(4) for other conditions. Most commonly used for overhead transmission lines, large industrial motor feeders, and utility distribution where conductors can be widely spaced. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(3) for proper MV copper conductor ampacity determination in isolated air installations providing maximum heat dissipation.
Table 315.60(C)(3).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for the basis of ampacities, 315.10(A) for conductor maximum operating temperature and application, and 315.60(D)(4) for the ampacity correction factors where the ambient air temperature is other than 40°C (104°F).

Table 315.60(C)(4).caption: Ampacities of Insulated Single Aluminum Conductor Isolated in Air
Table 315.60(C)(4).description: Provides highest ampacity ratings for single aluminum medium voltage conductors installed isolated in free air with maximum heat dissipation. Covers conductor sizes 8 AWG through 2000 kcmil with ratings for both MV-90 (90°C) and MV-105 (105°C) insulation types. Three voltage range columns: 2001-5000V, 5001-15000V, and 15001-35000V. Isolated installation means conductors spaced apart (not touching or bundled) allowing maximum cooling, resulting in highest possible ampacities for aluminum conductors. Aluminum ampacities are approximately 75-80% of equivalent copper ratings. Ampacities range from 64A for 8 AWG to 1475A for 2000 kcmil at highest temperature rating. Based on 40°C ambient temperature; requires correction factors from Table 315.60(D)(4) for other conditions. Used for overhead transmission lines, large industrial applications, and utility distribution where aluminum's cost advantages justify its use and conductors can be widely spaced for cooling. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(4) for proper MV aluminum conductor ampacity determination in isolated air installations.
Table 315.60(C)(4).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for the basis of ampacities, 315.10(A) for conductor maximum operating temperature and application, and 315.60(D)(4) for the ampacity correction factors where the ambient air temperature is other than 40°C (104°F).

Table 315.60(C)(5).caption: Ampacities of an Insulated Three-Conductor Copper Cable Isolated in Air
Table 315.60(C)(5).description: Provides ampacity ratings for three-conductor copper medium voltage cables with all three phases contained within a single cable assembly, installed isolated in free air. Covers conductor sizes 8 AWG through 1000 kcmil with ratings for both MV-90 (90°C) and MV-105 (105°C) insulation types. Separate columns for 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V voltage ranges. Three-conductor cable construction has all three phases under common jacket/sheath, resulting in lower ampacities than individual isolated single conductors due to mutual heating between conductors within the cable. Ampacities range from 59A for 8 AWG to 860A for 1000 kcmil. Based on 40°C ambient temperature; requires correction factors from Table 315.60(D)(4) for other conditions. Commonly used for underground duct banks, direct burial, and indoor installations where a single three-phase cable is preferred over pulling three separate cables. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(5) for proper MV three-conductor copper cable ampacity determination in isolated air installations.
Table 315.60(C)(5).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for the basis of ampacities, 315.10(A) for conductor maximum operating temperature and application, and 315.60(D)(4) for the ampacity correction factors where the ambient air temperature is other than 40°C (104°F).

Table 315.60(C)(6).caption: Ampacities of an Insulated Three-Conductor Aluminum Cable Isolated in Air
Table 315.60(C)(6).description: Provides ampacity ratings for three-conductor aluminum medium voltage cables with all three phases contained within a single cable assembly, installed isolated in free air. Covers conductor sizes 8 AWG through 1000 kcmil with ratings for both MV-90 (90°C) and MV-105 (105°C) insulation types. Separate columns for 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V voltage ranges. Aluminum three-conductor cable construction with all phases under common jacket/sheath results in lower ampacities than individual isolated conductors. Aluminum ampacities approximately 75-80% of equivalent copper cable ratings. Ampacities range from 46A for 8 AWG to 705A for 1000 kcmil. Based on 40°C ambient temperature; requires correction factors from Table 315.60(D)(4) for other conditions. Commonly used for underground duct banks, direct burial, and indoor installations where cost savings justify aluminum and single three-phase cable preferred over three separate cables. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(6) for proper MV three-conductor aluminum cable ampacity determination in isolated air installations.
Table 315.60(C)(6).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for the basis of ampacities, 315.10(A) for conductor maximum operating temperature and application, and 315.60(D)(4) for the ampacity correction factors where the ambient air temperature is other than 40°C (104°F).

Table 315.60(C)(7).caption: Ampacities of an Insulated Triplexed or Three Single-Conductor Copper Cables in Isolated Conduit in Air
Table 315.60(C)(7).description: Provides ampacity ratings for copper medium voltage conductors installed as three single conductors or triplexed set within an isolated conduit exposed to air. Covers conductor sizes 8 AWG through 1000 kcmil with ratings for both MV-90 (90°C) and MV-105 (105°C) insulation types. Separate columns for 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V voltage ranges. Installation method means conduit containing three-phase conductors is in free air (not buried or embedded) allowing external cooling, but conductors within conduit have reduced ampacity compared to isolated in free air due to conduit confinement limiting heat dissipation. Ampacities range from 55A for 8 AWG to 770A for 1000 kcmil. Based on 40°C ambient temperature; requires correction factors from Table 315.60(D)(4) for other conditions. Commonly used for above-ground conduit runs, rooftop installations, cable tray with conduit, and exposed conduit systems. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(7) for proper MV copper conductor ampacity determination in isolated conduit in air installations.
Table 315.60(C)(7).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for the basis of ampacities, 315.10(A) for conductor maximum operating temperature and application, and 315.60(D)(4) for the ampacity correction factors where the ambient air temperature is other than 40°C (104°F).

Table 315.60(C)(8).caption: Ampacities of an Insulated Triplexed or Three Single-Conductor Aluminum Cables in Isolated Conduit in Air
Table 315.60(C)(8).description: Provides ampacity ratings for aluminum medium voltage conductors installed as three single conductors or triplexed set within an isolated conduit exposed to air. Covers conductor sizes 8 AWG through 1000 kcmil with ratings for both MV-90 (90°C) and MV-105 (105°C) insulation types. Separate columns for 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V voltage ranges. Installation method means conduit containing three-phase conductors is in free air (not buried or embedded) allowing external cooling, but conductors within conduit have reduced ampacity compared to isolated in free air. Aluminum ampacities approximately 75-80% of equivalent copper ratings. Ampacities range from 43A for 8 AWG to 645A for 1000 kcmil. Based on 40°C ambient temperature; requires correction factors from Table 315.60(D)(4) for other conditions. Used for above-ground conduit runs, rooftop installations, cable tray with conduit, exposed conduit systems where aluminum cost savings justify its use. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(8) for proper MV aluminum conductor ampacity determination in isolated conduit in air installations.
Table 315.60(C)(8).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for the basis of ampacities, 315.10(A) for conductor maximum operating temperature and application, and 315.60(D)(4) for the ampacity correction factors where the ambient air temperature is other than 40°C (104°F).

Table 315.60(C)(9).caption: Ampacities of an Insulated Three-Conductor Copper Cable in Isolated Conduit in Air
Table 315.60(C)(9).description: Provides ampacity ratings for three-conductor copper medium voltage cable (all three phases in single cable assembly) installed within an isolated conduit exposed to air. Covers conductor sizes 8 AWG through 1000 kcmil with ratings for both MV-90 (90°C) and MV-105 (105°C) insulation types. Separate columns for 2001-5000V and 5001-35000V voltage ranges. Installation method means conduit containing three-conductor cable is in free air (not buried or embedded) allowing external cooling through conduit walls. Three-conductor cable already has mutual heating within cable jacket, plus additional heat confinement from conduit reduces ampacity compared to cable isolated in free air. Ampacities range from 52A for 8 AWG to 725A for 1000 kcmil. Based on 40°C ambient temperature; requires correction factors from Table 315.60(D)(4) for other conditions. Commonly used when pulling single three-phase cable through above-ground conduit, rooftop conduit runs, exposed industrial conduit systems. Required by NEC 315.60(C)(9) for proper MV three-conductor copper cable ampacity determination in isolated conduit in air.
Table 315.60(C)(9).note: Refer to 315.60(E) for the basis of ampacities, 315.10(A) for conductor maximum operating temperature and application, and 315.60(D)(4) for the ampacity correction factors where the ambient air temperature is other than 40°C (104°F).

Table 315.60(D)(4).caption: Ambient Temperature Correction Factors
Table 315.60(D)(4).description: For ambient temperatures other than 40°C (104°F), multiply the allowable ampacities specified in the ampacity tables by the appropriate factor shown below.

Table 326.112.caption: Paper Spacer Thickness
Table 326.112.description: Specifies required thickness of insulating paper spacers used in Type IGS (Integrated Gas-Insulated Transmission) cable construction. Paper spacers maintain proper conductor positioning within gas-insulated enclosure and provide mechanical support. Two thickness categories: 1.02mm (0.040 inch) for smaller conductors 250-1000 kcmil, and 1.52mm (0.060 inch) for larger conductors 1250-4750 kcmil. Thicker spacers for larger conductors ensure adequate mechanical support and maintain gas insulation gaps. Critical for maintaining electrical clearances in SF6 or gas-insulated environment. Used during IGS cable manufacturing and field assembly. Required by NEC 326.112 for proper IGS cable construction standards.

Table 326.116.caption: Conduit Dimensions
Table 326.116.description: Specifies outer and inner diameter dimensions for Type IGS (Integrated Gas-Insulated Transmission) cable conduit enclosures. IGS conduit is rigid gas-tight enclosure containing insulated conductor and pressurized insulating gas (typically SF6). Three sizes: 2-inch (53mm) with 1.947-inch ID, 3-inch (78mm) with 2.886-inch ID, 4-inch (103mm) with 3.710-inch ID. Wall thickness provides structural strength for gas pressure containment and mechanical protection. Critical for proper conductor fit, gas volume calculations, and installation planning. Used for determining cable pulling requirements and ensuring adequate clearances. Required by NEC 326.116 for IGS system design and installation.

Table 326.24.caption: Minimum Radii of Bends
Table 326.24.description: Specifies minimum bending radius requirements for Type IGS (Integrated Gas-Insulated Transmission) cable conduit to prevent damage during installation. IGS cable uses gas-insulated conductors in rigid conduit for high-capacity power transmission. Covers sizes 2-inch (53mm), 3-inch (78mm), and 4-inch (103mm) trade sizes. Minimum radii: 24 inches (600mm) for 2-inch, 35 inches (900mm) for 3-inch, 45 inches (1150mm) for 4-inch. Larger radii than standard conduit due to rigid gas-tight enclosure system. Critical for maintaining gas seal integrity and preventing conductor damage. Used in utility substations, generating stations, and industrial high-power applications. Required by NEC 326.24 for proper IGS cable installation.

Table 326.80.caption: Ampacity of Type IGS Cable
Table 326.80.description: Provides ampacity ratings for Type IGS (Integrated Gas-Insulated Transmission) cable conductors. IGS cable is high-capacity aluminum conductor surrounded by SF6 or similar insulating gas in sealed rigid conduit. Covers large conductor sizes 250 kcmil to 4750 kcmil for utility-scale transmission applications. Ampacity range: 119A (250 kcmil) to 519A (4750 kcmil). Lower ampacity than standard cable due to unique gas-insulated construction and heat dissipation characteristics. Used for generator connections, substation bus work, and high-power industrial feeders where space constraints require compact high-capacity installation. Common in generating stations, utility substations, and large industrial facilities. Required by NEC 326.80 for IGS cable sizing.

Table 344.30(B).caption: Supports for Rigid Metal Conduit
Table 344.30(B).description: Specifies maximum support spacing requirements for Rigid Metal Conduit (RMC) installations to prevent sagging and maintain proper alignment. RMC is heavy-duty galvanized steel or aluminum conduit for demanding applications. Support intervals based on conduit size: ½-¾ inch every 10 feet (3.0m), 1 inch every 12 feet (3.7m), 1¼-1½ inch every 14 feet (4.3m), 2-2½ inch every 16 feet (4.9m), 3 inch and larger every 20 feet (6.1m). Larger conduits permitted longer spans due to greater structural rigidity. Critical for both exposed and concealed installations. Applies to horizontal, vertical, and sloped runs. Required by NEC 344.30(B) for proper RMC support to prevent conductor damage and maintain code compliance.

Table 348.22.caption: Maximum Number of Insulated Conductors in Metric Designator 12 (Trade Size ⅜) Flexible Metal Conduit (FMC)*
Table 348.22.description: Specifies conductor fill limits for 3/8-inch (12mm) Flexible Metal Conduit (FMC), the smallest FMC size. Covers wire sizes 18-10 AWG across multiple insulation types: RFH-2/SF-2, TF/XHHW/TW, TFN/THHN/THWN, and FEP/FEPB/PF/PGF. Two installation scenarios: fittings inside FMC (more restrictive) vs. fittings outside FMC (allows more conductors). Maximum fills range from 1-8 conductors depending on wire size and insulation type. 3/8-inch FMC commonly used for short flex runs to motors, light fixtures, and equipment in tight spaces. One equipment grounding conductor of same size permitted in addition to listed conductor counts. Required by NEC 348.22 for proper 3/8-inch FMC fill calculations.
Table 348.22.note: *In addition, one insulated, covered, or bare equipment grounding conductor of the same size shall be permitted.

Table 352.30(B).caption: Support of Rigid Polyvinyl Chloride Conduit (PVC)
Table 352.30(B).description: Specifies maximum support spacing for rigid PVC conduit installations. PVC conduit requires closer support spacing than metal conduit due to lower structural strength and thermal expansion characteristics. Support intervals by size: ½-1 inch every 3 feet (900mm), 1¼-2 inch every 5 feet (1.5m), 2½-3 inch every 6 feet (1.8m), 3½-5 inch every 7 feet (2.1m), 6 inch every 8 feet (2.5m). Closer spacing required for smaller sizes. Critical for preventing sagging, especially in warm environments where PVC softens. Applies to both above-ground and exposed installations. More restrictive than metal conduit due to material properties. Required by NEC 352.30(B) for proper PVC conduit support and alignment.

Table 352.44(A).caption: Expansion Characteristics of PVC Rigid Nonmetallic Conduit Coefficient of Thermal Expansion = 6.084 × 10⁻⁵ mm/mm/°C (3.38 × 10⁻⁵ in./in./°F)
Table 352.44(A).description: Provides thermal expansion data for rigid PVC conduit to design expansion joints and prevent buckling or pulling from boxes. PVC expands significantly with temperature change (coefficient 6.084×10⁻⁵ per °C). Shows length change per meter (or per 100 feet) for temperature changes from 5°F to 200°F (5°C to 100°C). Example: 100°F temperature rise causes 4.06 inches expansion per 100 feet of PVC conduit. Critical for long conduit runs exposed to sunlight, rooftops, or outdoor installations with wide temperature swings. Expansion joints required when calculated movement exceeds ¼ inch. Used to determine expansion joint spacing and design. Common issue in desert climates and roof-mounted installations. Required by NEC 352.44(A) for thermal expansion calculations.

Table 354.24(A).caption: Minimum Bending Radius for Nonmetallic Underground Conduit with Conductors (NUCC)
Table 354.24(A).description: Specifies minimum bending radius for NUCC (Nonmetallic Underground Conduit with Conductors) to prevent conductor damage and maintain conduit integrity during and after installation. NUCC is direct-burial conduit factory-installed with conductors for underground distribution. Minimum radii increase with conduit size: ½ inch = 10 inches (250mm), ¾ inch = 12 inches (300mm), 1 inch = 14 inches (350mm), up to 4 inch = 60 inches (1500mm). Larger minimum radii than empty conduit due to pre-installed conductors that could be damaged by sharp bends. Critical during trenching, pulling, and placement operations. Used for underground service laterals, street lighting, and utility distribution systems. Required by NEC 354.24(A) for proper NUCC installation without conductor damage.

Table 355.30(B).caption: Support of Reinforced Thermosetting Resin Conduit (RTRC)
Table 355.30(B).description: Specifies maximum support spacing for RTRC (Reinforced Thermosetting Resin Conduit) installations. RTRC is fiberglass-reinforced resin conduit stronger than PVC with better heat resistance and dimensional stability. Support intervals identical to PVC Schedule 80: ½-1 inch every 3 feet (900mm), 1¼-2 inch every 5 feet (1.5m), 2½-3 inch every 6 feet (1.8m), 3½-5 inch every 7 feet (2.1m), 6 inch every 8 feet (2.5m). Despite superior material properties, same support spacing required as PVC due to thermal expansion concerns. Used in corrosive environments, chemical plants, and outdoor applications requiring non-metallic conduit with better performance than PVC. Required by NEC 355.30(B) for proper RTRC support.

Table 355.44.caption: Expansion Characteristics of Reinforced Thermosetting Resin Conduit (RTRC) Coefficient of Thermal Expansion = 2.7 × 10⁻⁵ mm/mm/°C (1.5 × 10⁻⁵ in./in./°F)
Table 355.44.description: Provides thermal expansion data for RTRC conduit installations. RTRC expands significantly less than PVC (coefficient 2.7×10⁻⁵ vs. 6.084×10⁻⁵ for PVC) - approximately 55% less thermal movement. Shows length change per meter (or per 100 feet) for temperature changes from 5°F to 200°F (5°C to 100°C). Example: 100°F temperature rise causes only 1.80 inches expansion per 100 feet of RTRC compared to 4.06 inches for PVC. Superior dimensional stability makes RTRC preferred for long runs in high-temperature environments. Expansion joints still required but spaced further apart than PVC. Common in outdoor industrial applications, rooftop installations, and corrosive environments. Required by NEC 355.44 for RTRC thermal expansion calculations.

Table 360.24(A).caption: Minimum Radii for Flexing Use
Table 360.24(A).description: Specifies minimum bending radius for FMT (Flexible Metallic Tubing) when installed in applications requiring repeated flexing or movement. FMT is lightweight flexible metallic raceway similar to flexible metal conduit but with thinner walls. Larger minimum radii required for flexing applications to prevent fatigue failure: 3/8 inch = 10 inches (254mm), 1/2 inch = 12.5 inches (317.5mm), 3/4 inch = 17.5 inches (444.5mm). More restrictive than fixed bend radii to accommodate repeated bending cycles. Common in machine tools, equipment subject to vibration, and applications where conduit flexes during normal operation. Critical for preventing metal fatigue and maintaining electrical continuity. Required by NEC 360.24(A) for FMT flexing installations.

Table 360.24(B).caption: Minimum Radii for Fixed Bends
Table 360.24(B).description: Specifies minimum bending radius for FMT (Flexible Metallic Tubing) in fixed installations where no repeated flexing occurs. FMT is lightweight flexible metallic raceway for dry locations. Smaller radii permitted for fixed bends: 3/8 inch = 3.5 inches (88.9mm), 1/2 inch = 4 inches (101.6mm), 3/4 inch = 5 inches (127mm). Less restrictive than flexing radii (Table 360.24(A)) since no fatigue concerns. Prevents kinking during installation and maintains adequate conductor fill area. Common for lighting fixtures, ceiling-mounted equipment, and short flex connections. Fixed bends set during installation and not subject to movement thereafter. Required by NEC 360.24(B) for proper FMT installation in fixed applications.

Table 384.22.caption: Channel Size and Inside Cross-Sectional Area
Table 384.22.description: Specifies dimensions and conductor fill areas for strut-type channel raceways (also called wireway or cable tray). Metal channel with removable covers for accessible wiring. Ten standard sizes from 1-5/8×15/16 inch (smallest) to 1-1/2×3 inch (largest). Provides total area, 40% fill area (for external joiners), and 25% fill area (for internal joiners). More restrictive 25% fill when joiners inside channel reduce usable space. Cross-sectional areas range from 0.887 in² to 4.308 in² total. Used for accessible industrial wiring, control circuits, and power distribution in commercial/industrial facilities. Allows easy conductor additions and changes. 40% or 25% fill limits prevent overheating and maintain accessibility. Required by NEC 384.22 for proper strut raceway conductor fill calculations.
footnotes: *Raceways with external joiners shall use a 40 percent wire fill calculation to determine the number of conductors permitted.
†Raceways with internal joiners shall use a 25 percent wire fill calculation to determine the number of conductors permitted.

Table 392.10(A).caption: Wiring Methods
Table 392.10(A).description: Comprehensive list of wiring methods and cable types permitted for installation in cable tray systems per NEC Article 392. Includes 33 different cable and conduit types from armored cable (AC) to underground feeder (UF). Covers power cables (MC, MI, SE, UF), communications/data cables (CATV, fiber optic, network), fire alarm cables, control cables (ITC, TC), and various conduit types (EMT, RMC, PVC, FMC, LFMC, etc.). Each entry references the applicable NEC article for detailed requirements. Cable trays provide organized, accessible support system for multiple cables in industrial, commercial, and utility installations. Most versatile raceway system accommodating widest range of wiring methods. Required by NEC 392.10(A) to determine permitted cable tray wiring methods.

Table 396.10(A).caption: Cable Types
Table 396.10(A).description: Lists cable types permitted for messenger-supported wiring installations per NEC Article 396. Messenger-supported wiring uses tensioned messenger wire (catenary wire) to support cables overhead, common in outdoor industrial facilities, between buildings, and utility applications. Eight permitted cable types: medium-voltage cable (Art. 315), metal-clad cable MC (Art. 330), mineral-insulated MI (Art. 332), multiconductor service-entrance SE/USE (Art. 338), underground feeder UF (Art. 340), power/control tray cable TC (Art. 336), power-limited tray cable, and other approved multiconductor cables. Messenger wire provides mechanical support while cables carry electrical load. Common in industrial plants, refineries, and outdoor distribution systems. Required by NEC 396.10(A) for permitted messenger-supported cable types.

Table 400.4.caption: Flexible Cords and Flexible Cables
Table 400.4.description: Comprehensive list of all NEC-recognized flexible cord and cable types with specifications. Over 90 cord types from lamp cord (Type C) to portable power cable (Type W). Details voltage ratings (300V-2000V), wire sizes, conductor counts, insulation types (thermoset/thermoplastic/elastomer), jacket materials, and usage categories (hard usage, extra-hard usage, pendant, portable). Includes specialty cords: electric vehicle (EV/EVT), elevator (E/EO), heater (HPD/HPN), vacuum cleaner (SV/SVT), range/dryer (SRD/SRDT), stage lighting (SC/SCE), and portable power (G/W/PPE). Usage categories: wet/damp locations, oil resistance, temperature ratings. Required by NEC 400.4 for all flexible cord applications.

notes: All types listed in Table 400.4 shall have individual conductors twisted together, except for Types HPN, HPD, SP-1, SP-2, SP-3, SPE-1, SPE-2, SPE-3, SPT-1, SPT-1W, SPT-2, SPT-2W, SPT-3, NISP-1, NISP-2, NISPE-1, NISPE-2, NISPT-1, and NISPT-2. Types HPN, HPD, SP-1, SP-2, SP-3, SPE-1, SPE-2, SPE-3, SPT-1, SPT-1W, SPT-2, SPT-2W, SPT-3, NISP-1, NISP-2, NISPE-1, NISPE-2, NISPT-1, and NISPT-2 shall be permitted to have the individual conductors in a flat parallel construction.

Insulated conductors of all cords, except those of heat-resistant cords, shall have a thermoset or thermoplastic insulation, except that the insulation on the individual conductors of Type G-GC cable shall be in accordance with 400.115.

All cords shall have a braided, woven, or knit outer covering or a thermoplastic jacket. For thermoset insulated conductors, a knit outer covering shall consist of 20 percent or more cotton and 80 percent or less synthetic fiber. For thermoplastic insulated conductors, a knit outer covering shall be integral with the insulation. Nonintegral thermoplastic outer coverings shall consist of a weave (such as straight fiber or twisted fiber) or braid construction. For hard usage cords, Types S, SE, SEW, SEO, SEOW, SEOO, and SEOOW, the outer covering shall be of nylon or other material of equal or better performance. For extra-hard usage cords, the outer covering shall consist of a weave of cotton, nylon, or other material of equivalent mechanical strength.

Elevator traveling cables for operating current and signal circuits, other than conductor sizes of Types E, EO, ETP, and ETT elevator cables, be permitted to incorporate in the construction one or more single-conductor or multiconductor communications cables. Types E, EO, ETP, and ETT elevator cables also be permitted to incorporate in the construction one or more communications cables, and one or more optical fiber cables, all of which shall be permitted to be color coded in accordance with 310.120, Table 310.120(C)(1). All cable conductors shall consist of a conductor, insulation, and a shield for use in either or all of the cable assemblies that shall not run solely through the center.

In systems grounded at the transformer or other source of supply, the neutral conductor shall have an outer covering. Neutral conductors not running with a control conductor shall be permitted to be cut short and a marker tape shall be used.

Minimum cable sizes for a corresponding grounding conductor may be integral with the conductors. The termination of the equipment grounding conductor for this cable shall be permitted to be by means of a special type of plug at the connection point of the cable. Types EV, EVE, EVJ, EVJE, EVT, and EVJT with a single-phase load current of 72 A or more at rated voltage shall have a braided shield over the power-carrying conductors. The shield requirements for three-phase cables shall be covered by cable assembly standards.

The required outer covering on some single-conductor cables may be integral with the insulation. Type cables for use in temporary installations of 29 days through 59 days and up to rated 600 volts, or over 29 days or rated 600 volts, 12 AWG or rated 600 volts. The three-phase cables that have straight conductors can be installed in 50,000 hours.
The third conductor on Type HPD shall be used as an equipment grounding conductor only. The insulation of the equipment grounding conductor for Type HPD shall be black with colored tracer.

Table 400.44(B)(1).caption: Thickness of Insulation for Three-Conductor Type G Portable Power Feeder Cables Rated 2000 Volts to 5000 Volts and Equipment Grounding Conductor Size
Table 400.44(B)(1).description: Specifications for Type G medium-voltage portable power feeder cables (2000V-5000V). Insulation thickness 110 mils (2.79mm) for all conductor sizes. Equipment grounding conductor sizing by power conductor size: 6 AWG uses 10 AWG ground, 4-2 AWG uses 8 AWG ground, up to 4/0 AWG uses 3 AWG ground. Three-conductor portable cables for mining, quarrying, tunneling, temporary substation power. Type G heavy-duty portable power cable. Required by NEC 400.44(B)(1) for medium-voltage portable cable specifications.

Table 400.44(B)(2).caption: Thickness of Insulation for Single Conductor Type SH Portable Power Feeder Cables Rated 2000 Volts to 25,000 Volts for 100 Percent Insulation Level
Table 400.44(B)(2).description: Insulation thickness requirements for Type SH single-conductor medium-voltage portable cables (2000V-25,000V). Four voltage ranges: 2001-5000V (110-120 mils), 5001-8000V (150 mils), 8001-15,000V (210 mils), 15,001-25,000V (295 mils). Thicker insulation for higher voltages. Conductor sizes 6 AWG to 500 kcmil. Type SH shielded thermoset portable cable for mining, quarrying, temporary power substations, utility construction. 100% insulation level means insulation rated for full line-to-line voltage. Required by NEC 400.44(B)(2) for Type SH cable insulation specs.

Table 400.44(B)(3).caption: Thickness of Insulation for Three-Conductor Type SHD and SHD-GC Portable Power Feeder Cables Rated 2000 Volts to 25,000 Volts for 100 Percent Insulation Level and 95 Volts and Grounding Conductor Size
Table 400.44(B)(3).description: Specifications for Type SHD and SHD-GC three-conductor medium-voltage portable cables (2000V-25,000V). Four voltage ranges with increasing insulation thickness: 2001-5000V (110-120 mils), 5001-8000V (150 mils), 8001-15,000V (210 mils), 15,001-25,000V (295 mils). Grounding conductor 8 AWG for all sizes. SHD has three grounding conductors in interstices, SHD-GC adds ground-check conductor. Individually shielded power conductors. For mining, quarrying, utility construction, temporary substations. Required by NEC 400.44(B)(3) for Type SHD/SHD-GC cable specs.

Table 400.44(B)(4).caption: Thickness of Insulation for Three-Conductor Type SHD-CGC Portable Power Feeder Cables Rated 2000 Volts to 5000 Volts for 100 Percent Insulation Level and Grounding Conductor Size
Table 400.44(B)(4).description: Specifications for Type SHD-CGC three-conductor portable cables (2000V-5000V). Insulation thickness 110 mils (2.79mm) for 6 AWG-4/0, 120 mils (3.05mm) for 250-500 kcmil. Equipment grounding conductor sized per power conductor: 6 AWG uses 10 AWG ground, increasing to 500 kcmil uses 2/0 ground. SHD-CGC has individually shielded power conductors, three grounding conductors, and one central ground-check conductor. For mining operations requiring ground continuity monitoring. Required by NEC 400.44(B)(4) for Type SHD-CGC cable specifications.

Table 400.5(A)(1).caption: Ampacity for Flexible Cords and Flexible Cables [Based on Ambient Temperature of 30°C (86°F). See 400.13 and Table 400.4.]
Table 400.5(A)(1).description: Ampacity ratings for most common flexible cord types at 30°C ambient. Three categories: thermoset types (C, E, S, SJ, SO, SP, SV types), thermoplastic types (ET, SE, SJT, SPE, SPT, ST, SRD, SVT types), and heater cords (HPD, HPN, HSJ types). Column A for 3 current-carrying conductors, Column B for 2 current-carrying conductors. Size range 27 AWG tinsel cord (0.5A) to 2 AWG (80-95A). Covers extension cords, appliance cords, vacuum cleaner cords, lamp cords, heater cords. Required by NEC 400.5(A)(1) for cord ampacity ratings.

Applied to base ampacity from Table 400.5(A)(1) or 400.5(A)(2). Common for multiconductor control cables, entertainment cables, multicore data/power cables. Grounding/bonding conductors not counted. Required by NEC 400.5(A)(3) for cord derating calculations.

Table 400.50.caption: Portable Power Feeder Cables
Table 400.50.description: Specifications for medium-voltage portable power feeder cable types (2000V-25,000V). Six cable types: Type G (2001-5000V, parallel sets), SHD-P-GG (2001-5000V, with control conductors), SH (2001-25,000V, single conductor), SHD (2001-25,000V, three grounding conductors), SHD-GC (2001-25,000V, with ground-check), SHD-CGC (2001-5000V, three grounds plus central ground-check). All use thermoset insulation and heavy-duty thermoset jackets. Shielded conductors for voltage stress control. For mining, quarrying, draglines, shovels, temporary power distribution. Required by NEC 400.50 for portable feeder cable type identification.

Size range 6 AWG (102-123A) to 500 kcmil (536-757A). Higher ampacity for single conductor due to better heat dissipation. Ampacity decreases slightly at higher voltages due to thicker insulation and dielectric losses. For Types SH, SHD, SHD-GC portable cables. Table 400.51(A)(2).caption: Adjustment Factors for Different Ambient Temperatures
Table 400.51(A)(2).description: Temperature correction factors for portable power feeder cables over 2000 volts. Base ampacity at 30°C (86°F). Five temperature ranges: 10°C (1.26x), 20°C (1.18x), 30°C (1.10x), 40°C (1.00x baseline), 50°C (0.90x). Higher ampacity in cooler environments due to better heat dissipation. Multiply Table 400.51(A)(1) ampacity by correction factor. Common for cables in cold climates, outdoor winter installations, underground cooling. Applies to Types SH, SHD, SHD-GC medium-voltage portable cables. Required by NEC 400.51(A)(2) for temperature correction.

Table 400.51(A)(3).caption: Adjustment Factors for Number of Layers of Cable Wound on a Reel
Table 400.51(A)(3).description: Derating factors for portable cables energized while wound on reels. Severe derating as layers increase: 1 layer (0.85x), 2 layers (0.65x), 3 layers (0.50x), 4 layers (0.35x). More than 4 layers requires engineering calculations. Heat cannot dissipate when cable coiled on reel. Common for welding cables, temporary power, construction sites, portable generators. Cable partially deployed from storage reel. Apply factor to Table 400.51(A)(1) base ampacity. Prevents overheating and insulation damage. Required by NEC 400.51(A)(3) for reel-mounted cable derating.
Table 400.51(A)(3).note: *If more than four layers of cable are wound on the reel, ampacity derating should be calculated using engineering supervision.
