Table 408.5.caption: Clearance for Conductors Entering Bus Enclosures
Table 408.5.description: Minimum clearances for feeder/service conductors entering switchboard/panelboard bus enclosures. Insulated busbars: 8 inches (200mm) clearance. Noninsulated (bare) busbars: 10 inches (250mm) clearance. Larger clearance for bare busbars due to shock/arc flash hazard. Measured from conductor entry point to busbar, supports, or obstructions. Ensures safe conductor bending radius and working space. Applies to service entrance conductors, large feeders entering distribution equipment. Prevents accidental contact during maintenance. Required by NEC 408.5 for safe conductor-to-bus clearances.

rows.conductor: Insulated busbars, their supports, or other obstructions

Table 408.56.caption: Minimum Spacings Between Bare Metal Parts
Table 408.56.description: Minimum electrical clearances for bare (uninsulated) busbars and terminals in switchboards and panelboards. Three voltage categories: ≤125V (3/4 inch opposite polarity), ≤250V (1-1/4 inch opposite polarity), ≤1000V (2 inch opposite polarity). Three spacing types: opposite polarity same surface (largest), opposite polarity held in air (medium), live parts to ground (smallest). Larger spacings at higher voltages to prevent arc-over, flashover. Critical for busbar design, terminal arrangements. Prevents short circuits and arc flash incidents. Common in 480V panelboards, 208V switchboards. Required by NEC 408.56 for safe bare conductor spacing.
Table 408.56.note: *For spacing between live parts and doors of cabinets, the dimensions in 312.101(A) shall apply.

Table 424.3.caption: Other Articles
Table 424.3.description: Cross-reference table for Article 424 (Fixed Electric Space-Heating Equipment) directing to related articles. References Article 440 Parts I-VI for air-conditioning and refrigerating equipment that includes heating functions. Important when fixed space heaters integrated with HVAC systems, heat pumps combining heating/cooling. Ensures proper application of motor rules, overload protection, disconnecting means for combination heating-cooling equipment. Prevents overlooking critical safety requirements in dual-function equipment. Required by NEC 424.3 for cross-article compliance.

rows.article: 440 (Parts I, II, III, IV, V, VI)

Table 425.3.caption: Other Articles
Table 425.3.description: Cross-reference table for Article 425 (Fixed Resistance and Electrode Industrial Process Heating Equipment). References Article 430 for motors/motor circuits/controllers, Article 440 Parts I-IV for air-conditioning/refrigeration. Industrial heating often includes conveyors, fans, pumps requiring motor rules. Heat treatment, induction heating, resistance heating in manufacturing. Ensures proper motor overload protection, disconnecting means, controller sizing. Common in metal treatment, plastic forming, chemical processing. Required by NEC 425.3 for comprehensive industrial heating system compliance.

Table 426.3.caption: Other Articles
Table 426.3.description: Cross-reference table for Article 426 (Fixed Outdoor Electric Deicing and Snow-Melting Equipment). References Article 422 Parts I-V for appliances. Snow-melting systems for driveways, walkways, ramps, gutters, roofs. Deicing prevents ice dams, snow accumulation. References appliance rules for control requirements, disconnecting means, grounding, installation. Common in commercial buildings, hospitals, parking structures, residential driveways. Ensures proper GFCI protection, control circuits, heating cable installation. Required by NEC 426.3 for outdoor heating system compliance.

Table 427.3.caption: Other Articles
Table 427.3.description: Cross-reference table for Article 427 (Fixed Electric Heating Equipment for Pipelines and Vessels). References Article 422 Parts I-V for appliances. Pipe tracing prevents freezing in water lines, fuel lines, chemical process pipes. Vessel heating for tanks, drums, hoppers. Heat tape, heating cable, impedance heating. References appliance rules for control requirements, disconnecting means, grounding. Common in refineries, chemical plants, water treatment, freeze protection. Ensures proper installation of heating elements, controllers, temperature sensors. Required by NEC 427.3 for pipeline/vessel heating compliance.

Table 430.10(B).caption: Minimum Wire-Bending Space at the Terminals of Enclosed Motor Controllers
Table 430.10(B).description: Minimum bending space requirements for conductors at motor controller terminals to prevent insulation damage. Wire sizes 8 AWG (1.5 inches) to 900 kcmil (18-19 inches). Two columns: 1 wire per terminal (smaller space), 2 wires per terminal (larger space). Larger wires need more bending radius. Not specified for 10 AWG and smaller. Ensures adequate room for conductor installation and prevents over-bending that damages insulation. Common for motor starters, combination motor controllers, MCC buckets. Required by NEC 430.10(B) for motor controller wire-bending clearance.
Table 430.10(B).note: Where provision for three or more wires per terminal exists, the minimum wire-bending space shall be in accordance with the requirements of 312.6(B).

Table 430.12(B).caption: Terminal Housings — Wire-to-Wire Connections
Table 430.12(B).description: Minimum terminal box (junction box) sizes for motor wire-to-wire connections. Three categories: small motors ≤11 inch diameter (1 HP to 15 HP), large AC motors >11 inch diameter (by FLA), DC motors (by FLA). Specifies cover opening minimum dimension and usable volume in cubic inches/cm³. Small motors: 1 HP (10.5 in³) to 15 HP (36.4 in³). Large motors: 45A (36.4 in³) to 600A (1540 in³). Ensures adequate space for splicing, wire nuts, connectors. Common for motors with separate terminal boxes. Required by NEC 430.12(B) for motor terminal housing sizing.

sections.section: Motors 275 mm (11 in.) in Diameter or Less
Motors Over 275 mm (11 in.) in Diameter — Alternating-Current Motors

notes: Note: Auxiliary leads for such items as brakes, thermostats, space heaters, and exciting fields shall be permitted to be neglected if their current-carrying area does not exceed 25 percent of the current-carrying area of the motor power leads.

*For motors rated 1 hp and smaller, and with the terminal housing partially or wholly integral with the frame or end shield, the volume of the terminal housing shall be not less than 18.0 cm³ (1.1 in.³) per wire-to-wire connection. The minimum cover opening dimension is not specified.

^bFor motors rated 1½, 2, and 3 hp, and with the terminal housing partially or wholly integral with the frame or end shield, the volume of the terminal housing shall be not less than 23.0 cm³ (1.4 in.³) per wire-to-wire connection. The minimum cover opening dimension is not specified.

Table 430.12(C)(1).caption: Terminal Spacings — Fixed Terminals
Table 430.12(C)(1).description: Minimum electrical clearances between fixed terminals in motor terminal housings. Two voltage categories: ≤250V (1/4 inch spacing), 251-1000V (3/8 inch spacing). Two spacing types: between line terminals (phase-to-phase), between line terminals and uninsulated metal (phase-to-ground). Prevents short circuits, arc-over, flashover in motor terminal boxes. Critical for motors with integral terminal boards, lug connections. Larger spacing for higher voltage motors. Common in 480V motors requiring 3/8 inch clearance. Required by NEC 430.12(C)(1) for motor terminal electrical spacing.

Table 430.22(E).caption: Duty-Cycle Service
Table 430.22(E).description: Conductor sizing percentages for non-continuous duty motors. Four duty classifications: short-time (valves, rolls, 110-150%), intermittent (elevators, pumps, 85-140%), periodic (ore handlers, 85-140%), varying duty (110-200%). Percentages multiply motor nameplate FLA for conductor ampacity. Motors rated for 5-minute, 15-minute, 30-60 minute, or continuous duty have different factors. Intermittent duty allows smaller conductors than continuous. Common for elevators, cranes, drawbridges, damper operators, valve actuators. Prevents conductor oversizing for non-continuous loads. Required by NEC 430.22(E) for duty-cycle motor conductor sizing.

rows.classification_of_service: Short-time duty operating valves, raising or lowering rolls, etc.
Intermittent duty freight and passenger elevators, tool heads, pumps, drawbridges, turntables, etc. (for arc welders, see 630.11)
Periodic duty rolls, ore- and coal-handling machines, etc.

Table 430.22(E).note: Any motor application shall be considered as continuous duty unless the nature of the apparatus it drives is such that the motor will not operate continuously with load under any condition of use.

Table 430.23(C).caption: Secondary Conductor
Table 430.23(C).description: Secondary conductor sizing for wound-rotor motors with external resistors. Seven duty classifications based on starting frequency and duration. Light starting (35%), heavy starting (45%), extra-heavy starting (55%), light intermittent (65%), medium intermittent (75%), heavy intermittent (85%), continuous (110%). Percentages of full-load secondary current. Lighter duty allows smaller conductors due to reduced heating. Common for large motors with soft-start resistors, cranes, hoists, mills. Secondary conductors connect motor slip rings to external resistor banks. Required by NEC 430.23(C) for wound-rotor motor secondary conductor sizing.

Table 430.247.caption: Full-Load Current in Amperes, Direct-Current Motors
Table 430.247.description: Full-load amperage (FLA) for DC motors at base speed. Six voltage columns: 90V, 120V, 180V, 240V, 500V, 550V. Motor sizes 1/4 HP (1.6-4.0A) to 200 HP (294-675A). Lower voltage requires higher current for same horsepower. Used for sizing conductors (multiply FLA by 125%), overload protection (115%-125% FLA), branch circuit protection (150% FLA). Common DC motor applications: cranes, hoists, elevators, traction, adjustable speed drives. Essential reference table for all DC motor electrical design. Required by NEC 430.247 for DC motor full-load current values.

Table 430.248.caption: Full-Load Currents in Amperes, Single-Phase Alternating-Current Motors
Table 430.248.description: Full-load amperage (FLA) for single-phase AC motors. Four voltage columns: 115V, 200V, 208V, 230V. Motor sizes 1/6 HP (2.2-4.4A) to 10 HP (50-100A). Most common residential/light commercial motors. Used for sizing conductors (125% FLA), overload protection (115-125% FLA), branch circuit protection (250% FLA inverse time breaker). Typical applications: air compressors, pumps, fans, garage door openers, table saws, well pumps. 230V draws half the current of 115V for same HP. Essential for all single-phase motor calculations. Required by NEC 430.248 for single-phase AC motor FLA values.

Table 430.249.caption: Full-Load Current, Two-Phase Alternating-Current Motors (4-Wire)
Table 430.249.description: Full-load amperage (FLA) for two-phase AC motors (4-wire systems). Five voltage columns: 115V, 230V, 460V, 575V, 2300V. Motor sizes 1/2 HP (0.8-4.0A) to 200 HP (43-416A). Two-phase systems rare today but found in older installations, Scott-T transformer systems. Common conductor in 3-wire 2-phase system carries 1.41x listed current. Used for conductor sizing (125% FLA), overload protection, branch circuit protection. Historical installations: early industrial plants, older textile mills. Required by NEC 430.249 for two-phase motor FLA values.

Table 430.250.caption: Full-Load Current, Three-Phase Alternating-Current Motors
Table 430.250.description: Most critical motor table: Full-load amperage (FLA) for three-phase AC motors. Two sections: induction motors (squirrel-cage and wound-rotor) and synchronous motors (unity power factor). Voltages: 115V, 200V, 208V, 230V, 460V, 575V, 2300V. Induction motors 1/2 HP (0.9-4.4A) to 500 HP (118-590A). Synchronous motors 25 HP to 200 HP at unity PF. Used for all three-phase motor calculations: conductor sizing (125% FLA), overload protection (115-125% FLA), branch circuit protection (Table 430.52). Most common industrial/commercial motors: pumps, fans, compressors, conveyors. 460V motors most common. Essential reference for electricians. Required by NEC 430.250 for 3-phase motor FLA.

sections.section: Induction-Type Squirrel Cage and Wound Rotor (Amperes)

Table 430.250.note: *For 90 and 80 percent power factor, the figures shall be multiplied by 1.1 and 1.25, respectively.

Table 430.251(A).caption: Conversion Table of Single-Phase Locked-Rotor Currents for Selection of Disconnecting Means and Controllers as Determined from Horsepower and Voltage Rating
Table 430.251(A).description: Locked-rotor (starting) amperage for single-phase motors used to size disconnects and controllers. Three voltages: 115V, 208V, 230V. Motor sizes 1/2 HP (29.4-58.8A LRA) to 10 HP (300-1000A LRA). Starting current 6-10x higher than FLA. Critical for sizing motor disconnect switches, combination starters, fused disconnects per NEC 430.110. Also applies to HVAC equipment disconnects (440.12) and controllers (440.41). Higher inrush at lower voltage. Used with horsepower rating when locked-rotor code not marked on nameplate. Required by NEC 430.251(A) for single-phase motor disconnect/controller selection.

Table 430.251(B).caption: Conversion Table of Polyphase Design B, C, and D Maximum Locked-Rotor Currents for Selection of Disconnecting Means and Controllers as Determined from Horsepower and Voltage Rating and Design Letter
Table 430.251(B).description: Maximum locked-rotor (starting) amperage for three-phase Design B, C, D motors for disconnect/controller sizing. Six voltages: 115V, 200V, 208V, 230V, 460V, 575V. Motor sizes 1/2 HP (8-40A LRA) to 500 HP (2900-3625A LRA). Design B most common (general purpose), Design C (high starting torque), Design D (extra-high starting torque). Design A motors not covered (no LRA limit). Used when locked-rotor code letter not on nameplate. Critical for sizing motor disconnects (430.110), HVAC disconnects (440.12), controllers. Required by NEC 430.251(B) for three-phase motor disconnect/controller selection.
Table 430.251(B).note: *Design A motors are not limited to a maximum starting current or locked rotor current.

Table 430.29.caption: Conductor Rating Factors for Power Resistors
Table 430.29.description: Conductor sizing for motor starting/braking resistor banks based on duty cycle. Seven categories from light intermittent to continuous. Time ON (5-15 seconds) vs time OFF (15-75 seconds) determines ampacity percentage (35%-110%). Shorter ON time with longer OFF time allows smaller conductors. Light duty 5 sec ON/75 sec OFF = 35%. Continuous duty = 110%. Common for wound-rotor motors, dynamic braking, speed control. Resistor bank conductors heat during motor acceleration/deceleration. Required by NEC 430.29 for resistor conductor sizing.

Table 430.37.caption: Overload Units
Table 430.37.description: Number and location of overload relays required by motor type and electrical system. Single-phase motors: 1 overload in ungrounded conductor. Two-phase motors: 2 overloads, one per phase. Three-phase motors: 3 overloads, one per phase. Grounded systems require overloads only in ungrounded conductors. Overload relays protect motor from running overload (not short circuits). Common applications: motor starters, combination starters. Critical for preventing motor burnout from overload conditions. Exception allows alternative protection methods. Required by NEC 430.37 for overload protection requirements.

rows.supply_system: 2-wire, 1-phase ac or dc, one conductor grounded
3-wire, 1-phase ac or dc, grounded neutral conductor

rows.number_and_location_of_overload_units: 2, one for each phase in ungrounded conductors
2, one for each phase in any ungrounded phase wire

Table 430.37.note: *Exception: An overload unit in each phase shall not be required where overload protection is provided by other approved means.

Table 430.5.caption: Other Articles
Table 430.5.description: Comprehensive cross-reference table for Article 430 (Motors, Motor Circuits, Controllers) directing to 14 specialized articles. References: HVAC (440), capacitors (460), hazardous locations (500-506), elevators (620), cranes (610), fire pumps (695), irrigation machines (675), industrial machinery (670), transformers (450), theaters (520/540), garages/hangars (511-517). Critical for special motor applications requiring additional safety rules beyond Article 430. Ensures compliance with occupancy-specific and equipment-specific requirements. Required by NEC 430.5 for comprehensive motor installation compliance.

rows.equipment_occupancy: Commercial garages; aircraft hangars; motor fuel dispensing facilities; bulk storage plants; spray application, dipping, and coating processes; and inhalation anesthetizing locations
Electrically driven or controlled irrigation machines
Elevators, dumbwaiters, escalators, moving walks, wheelchair lifts, and stairway chair lifts
Motion picture and television studios and similar locations
Theaters, audience areas of motion picture and television studios, and similar locations

Table 430.52(C)(1).caption: Maximum Rating or Setting of Motor Branch-Circuit Short-Circuit and Ground-Fault Protective Devices
Table 430.52(C)(1).description: Critical table for sizing motor branch circuit protection (fuses/breakers) as percentage of motor FLA. Four device types: nontime-delay fuse, dual-element time-delay fuse, instantaneous trip breaker, inverse time breaker. Seven motor types: single-phase (300%/175%/800%/250%), polyphase squirrel-cage (300%/175%/800%/250%), Design B high-efficiency (300%/175%/1100%/250%), synchronous (300%/175%/800%/250%), wound-rotor (150%/150%/800%/150%), DC (150%/150%/250%/150%). Protects against short circuits/ground faults, NOT overloads. Most common: dual-element fuse at 175% or inverse time breaker at 250%. Required by NEC 430.52 for motor branch circuit protection sizing.

rows.type_of_motor: AC polyphase motors other than wound-rotor
Squirrel cage — other than Design B energy-efficient — and Design B premium efficiency
Design B energy-efficient and Design B premium efficiency

notes: See 430.54 for certain exceptions to the values specified.
The values in the Nontime Delay Fuse column apply to time-delay Class CC fuses.
The values given in the last column also cover the ratings of nonadjustable inverse time types of circuit breakers that can be modified as in 430.52(C)(1)(a) and (b).

Synchronous motors of the low-torque, low-speed type (usually 450 rpm or lower), such as those used to drive reciprocating compressors, pumps, and so forth, that start unloaded, do not require a fuse rating or circuit breaker setting in excess of 200 percent of full-load current.

Table 430.7(B).caption: Locked-Rotor Indicating Code Letters
Table 430.7(B).description: Code letter classification for motor locked-rotor (starting) current in kVA per horsepower. 19 code letters A through V (no I or O). Code A lowest (0-3.14 kVA/HP), Code V highest (22.4+ kVA/HP). Higher code letters indicate higher starting current. Critical for sizing motor branch circuit protective devices, determining voltage drop during starting. Code stamped on motor nameplate. Common codes: B-D (small motors), F-H (general purpose), J-L (high efficiency), P-V (high-torque starting). Used with Table 430.52 for branch circuit protection sizing. Required by NEC 430.7(B) for motor starting characteristics.

Table 430.72(B)(2).caption: Maximum Rating of Overcurrent Protective Device in Amperes
Table 430.72(B)(2).description: Maximum overcurrent protection for motor control circuit conductors. Three columns: A (basic ampacity limits), B (higher for control transformers 400% of ampacity), C (300% for other applications). Wire sizes 18 AWG (7A) to >10 AWG. Column A: 18 AWG limited to 7A, 16 AWG to 10A. Column B allows higher protection: 18 AWG up to 25A, 14 AWG up to 100A, 12 AWG up to 120A. Control circuits for motor starters, contactors, pushbutton stations. Small conductors protected from overload while allowing magnetic inrush. Required by NEC 430.72(B)(2) for control circuit protection sizing.
notes: 1. Value specified in 310.15 as applicable.
2. 400 percent of value specified in Table 310.17 for 60°C conductors.
3. 300 percent of value specified in Table 310.16 for 60°C conductors.

Table 430.97(D).caption: Minimum Spacing Between Bare Metal Parts
Table 430.97(D).description: Minimum electrical clearances for bare busbars and terminals in motor control centers (MCCs). Three voltage categories: ≤125V (3/4 inch opposite polarity), ≤250V (1-1/4 inch opposite polarity), ≤600V (2 inch opposite polarity). Three spacing types: opposite polarity same surface, opposite polarity held free in air, live parts to ground. Identical to Table 408.56 but specific to MCCs. Larger spacings at higher voltages prevent arc-over. Critical for MCC busbar design, motor bucket layout. Common in 480V MCCs requiring 2 inch phase-to-phase clearance. Required by NEC 430.97(D) for MCC bare conductor spacing.

Table 450.3(A).caption: Maximum Rating or Setting of Overcurrent Protection for Transformers Over 1000 Volts (as a Percentage of Transformer-Rated Current)
Table 450.3(A).description: Overcurrent protection sizing for medium-voltage transformers (>1000V). Based on transformer impedance (≤6%, 6-10%) and location (any, supervised). Primary protection: breaker 300-600%, fuse 250-300%. Secondary protection over 1000V: breaker 250-300%, fuse 225-250%. Secondary ≤1000V: 125-250%. Lower percentages for supervised locations. Supervised locations (qualified personnel only) may omit secondary protection in some cases. Applies to utility transformers, substation transformers, industrial distribution. Coordinated thermal overload allows higher primary protection. Required by NEC 450.3(A) for medium-voltage transformer protection.

rows.transformer_rated_impedance: More than 6% and not more than 10%
More than 6% and not more than 10%

notes: ¹Where the required fuse rating or circuit breaker setting does not correspond to a standard rating or setting, a higher rating or setting that does not exceed the next higher standard rating shall be permitted.

²Where secondary overcurrent protection is required, the secondary overcurrent device shall be permitted to consist of not more than six circuit breakers or six sets of fuses grouped in one location. Where multiple overcurrent devices are utilized, the total of all the device ratings shall not exceed the allowed value of a single overcurrent device. If both circuit breakers and fuses are utilized, the total of the device ratings shall not exceed that allowed for fuses.
³(2) The next higher commercially available rating or setting for fuses and circuit breakers above 1000 volts.

⁴Where secondary overcurrent protection is required, the secondary overcurrent device shall be permitted to consist of not more than six circuit breakers or six sets of fuses grouped in one location. Where multiple overcurrent devices are utilized, the total of all the device ratings shall not exceed the allowed value of a single overcurrent device. If both circuit breakers and fuses are utilized, the total of the device ratings shall not exceed that allowed for fuses.
⁵A supervised location is a location where conditions of maintenance and supervision ensure that only qualified persons monitor and service the transformer installation.
⁶Electronically actuated fuses that may be set to open at a specific current shall be set in accordance with settings for circuit breakers.

⁷A transformer equipped with a coordinated thermal overload protection by the manufacturer and arranged to interrupt the primary current shall be permitted to have primary overcurrent protection rated or set at a current value that is not more than six times the rated current of the transformer for transformers having not more than 6 percent impedance and not more than four times the rated current of the transformer for transformers having more than 6 percent but not more than 10 percent impedance.

Table 450.3(B).caption: Maximum Rating or Setting of Overcurrent Protection for Transformers 1000 Volts and Less (as a Percentage of Transformer-Rated Current)
Table 450.3(B).description: Overcurrent protection sizing for low-voltage transformers (≤1000V). Two methods: primary-only protection or primary-and-secondary protection. Primary-only: 125% for ≥9A primary, 167% for <9A, 300% for <2A, no secondary required. Primary-and-secondary: 250% primary (any current), 125% secondary for ≥9A, 167% for <9A. Common applications: 480V-208V/120V transformers, control transformers, dry-type transformers. Secondary may use up to 6 breakers/fuses grouped. Most common: primary-only at 125%. Required by NEC 450.3(B) for low-voltage transformer protection.
notes: ¹Where 125 percent of this current does not correspond to a standard rating of a fuse or nonadjustable circuit breaker, a higher rating that does not exceed the next higher standard rating shall be permitted.

²Where secondary overcurrent protection is required, the secondary overcurrent device shall be permitted to consist of not more than six circuit breakers or six sets of fuses grouped in one location. Where multiple overcurrent devices are utilized, the total of all the device ratings shall not exceed the allowed value of a single overcurrent device.

³A transformer equipped with coordinated thermal overload protection by the manufacturer and arranged to interrupt the primary current shall be permitted to have primary overcurrent protection rated or set at a current value that is not more than six times the rated current of the transformer for transformers having not more than 6 percent impedance and not more than four times the rated current of the transformer for transformers having more than 6 percent but not more than 10 percent impedance.

Table 495.24.caption: Minimum Clearance of Live Parts
Table 495.24.description: Minimum electrical clearances for medium/high-voltage equipment over 1000 volts. Voltage range 2.4kV to 230kV. Based on Basic Impulse Level (BIL) rating. Indoor and outdoor clearances: phase-to-phase and phase-to-ground. Low voltage (2.4-4.16kV): 3-7 inches. Medium voltage (13.8-34.5kV): 5-18 inches. High voltage (69-230kV): 21-105 inches. Outdoor clearances larger due to weather. BIL determines insulation withstand. For switchgear, substations, transformers, circuit breakers, busbars. Prevents flashover, arc-over. Increase for conductor movement, unfavorable conditions. Required by NEC 495.24 for equipment over 1000V clearances.
Table 495.24.note: The values given are the minimum clearance for rigid parts and bare conductors under favorable service conditions. They shall be increased for conductor movement or under unfavorable service conditions or wherever space limitations permit. The selection of the associated impulse withstand voltage for a particular system voltage is determined by the characteristics of the overvoltage(surge) protective equipment.

Chapter 9 Table 4.caption: Dimensions and Percent Area of Conduit and Tubing
Chapter 9 Table 4.description: Provides internal cross-sectional areas for various conduit types. Shows area available for conductor fill at different percentages. For 3 or more conductors, use 40% fill per Chapter 9 Table 1.

notes.text: 40% fill is used for 3 or more conductors per Chapter 9 Table 1.
31% fill is used for 2 conductors. 53% fill is used for 1 conductor.
EMT = Electrical Metallic Tubing. RMC = Rigid Metal Conduit. IMC = Intermediate Metal Conduit.
PVC-40 = Schedule 40 PVC. PVC-80 = Schedule 80 PVC.

Chapter 9 Table 5.caption: Dimensions of Insulated Conductors and Fixture Wires
Chapter 9 Table 5.description: Provides approximate cross-sectional area of insulated conductors for conduit fill calculations. Use with Chapter 9 Table 4 to determine maximum conductors per conduit.

notes.text: Areas are approximate and include insulation thickness.
THHN/THWN-2 have the smallest insulation, allowing more conductors per conduit.
For compact stranded conductors, use Chapter 9 Table 5A.

Chapter 9 Table 8.caption: Conductor Properties
Chapter 9 Table 8.description: DC resistance at 75°C (167°F) in ohms per 1000 feet for uncoated copper and aluminum conductors. Used for voltage drop calculations per 210.19(A)(1) Informational Note No. 4. Values based on stranded conductors except for solid wire sizes 14-10 AWG.
notes: These resistance values are valid at 75°C (167°F). For other temperatures, resistance increases approximately 0.393% per degree C for copper and 0.403% per degree C for aluminum.
For voltage drop calculations, use the formula: VD = (2 × L × R × I) / 1000, where L = one-way length in feet, R = resistance per 1000 ft, I = current in amperes.
The 3% voltage drop limit for branch circuits and 5% total (branch + feeder) are recommendations per 210.19(A)(1) Informational Note No. 4.
